articles.headline: Outsourcing Works, So India Is Exporting Jobs
articles.snippet: Indian outsourcing companies are hiring workers and opening offices in other developing countries.
articles.abstract: Indian outsourcing companies are hiring workers and opening offices in other developing countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYSORE, India — Thousands of Indians report to Infosys Technologies’ campus here to learn the finer points of programming. Lately, though, packs of foreigners have been roaming the manicured lawns, too.

articles.headline: Ahmadinejad, at Columbia, Parries and Puzzles
articles.snippet: In a hostile environment at Columbia University, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran meandered from science and religion to politics.
articles.abstract: In a hostile environment at Columbia University, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran meandered from science and religion to politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: He said that there were no homosexuals in Iran — not one — and that the Nazi slaughter of six million Jews should not be treated as fact, but theory, and therefore open to debate and more research.

articles.headline: Microsoft Is Said to Consider a Stake in Facebook
articles.snippet: The company is considering an investment of between $300 million and $500 million for less than 5 percent of Facebook.
articles.abstract: The company is considering an investment of between $300 million and $500 million for less than 5 percent of Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 — Some people laughed at Mark E. Zuckerberg when he reportedly turned down a $900 million offer last year for Facebook, the social networking Web site he founded three and a half years ago.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: On Strike at G.M., Resolute but Anxious About Future
articles.snippet: Workers at the General Motors pickup plant in Pontiac, Michigan said they were preparing themselves for the possibility of spending months out of work.
articles.abstract: Workers at the General Motors pickup plant in Pontiac, Michigan said they were preparing themselves for the possibility of spending months out of work.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 24 — They had not expected a strike this year. And when they walked out midway through the morning shift on Monday, the workers at the General Motors pickup truck plant here had no idea how long their walkout would last.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Mary M. Chapman

articles.headline: 73,000 U.A.W. Members Go on Strike Against G.M.
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers union wielded its most potent weapon, sending workers to picket lines in its first national strike at G.M. since 1970.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers union wielded its most potent weapon, sending workers to picket lines in its first national strike at G.M. since 1970.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union wielded its most potent weapon against General Motors yesterday, sending 73,000 workers to picket lines in its first national strike at G.M. since 1970.

articles.headline: Approval Is Sought to Build Two Reactors in Texas
articles.snippet: In a bid to take the lead in the race to revive the nuclear power industry, NRG Energy will ask federal authorities Tuesday for permission to build two reactors in Texas.
articles.abstract: In a bid to take the lead in the race to revive the nuclear power industry, NRG Energy will ask federal authorities Tuesday for permission to build two reactors in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 — In a bid to take the lead in the race to revive the nuclear power industry, an energy company will ask the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Tuesday for permission to build two reactors in Texas.

articles.headline: The Loan That Keeps On Taking
articles.snippet: Lawsuits are being filed on behalf of borrowers who legal advocates say were sold homes beyond their means.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits are being filed on behalf of borrowers who legal advocates say were sold homes beyond their means.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The Torralba family’s taste of the American dream began to sour in May 2006, two months after they bought a modest home at the southern end of Silicon Valley, when they received notice from a man who claimed that they owed him money.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: World Bank Faces Doubt From Donors
articles.snippet: Wealthy countries are balking at financing World Bank projects because of their own budget problems and lingering questions over the bank’s relevance.
articles.abstract: Wealthy countries are balking at financing World Bank projects because of their own budget problems and lingering questions over the bank’s relevance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 — Girls’ schools in Bangladesh, clean water systems in Ghana, courthouses in Armenia, roads in Nicaragua. For decades, the World Bank has financed more than $10 billion a year for projects like these, the biggest source of aid for the poorest countries.
